Consider a complex valued function \\( z(t) \\) described by the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a real constant. We analyze the impact of the transformation defined by the function \\( f(z) = e^{i\\theta t}z \\) over time t, where \\( \\theta \\) is also a real constant.

If \\( f(z) \\) is applied to a vector \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\) without further intervention, will \\( z(t) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T under \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( f(z) \\) changes the initial condition by adding a phase shift of \\( i\\theta t \\). The subsequent evolution under \\( \\dot{z} = i\\omega z \\) means the system's behavior will include the effects of both \\( \\omega \\) and \\( \\theta \\), leading to \\( z(T) = e^{i(\\omega + \\theta)T} z_0 \\) rather than \\( e^{i\\omega T} z_0 \\).
